response:
although it's difficult to diagnose your condition online without any physical examination, the symptoms you're describing are more suggestive of a condition called cubital tunnel syndrome. this condition occurs when the ulnar nerve, which passes through a tunnel of tissue (the cubital tunnel) on the inside of the elbow, becomes compressed or irritated. the typical symptoms include numbness and tingling in the pinky and ring fingers, especially when the elbow is bent. 

in contrast, carpal tunnel syndrome typically affects the thumb, index, and middle fingers. while some of your description also fits the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (such as tingling with prolonged positions of the wrist), the involvement of the pinky and ring finger is indicative of ulnar nerve compression rather than median nerve compression (which is found in carpal tunnel syndrome).

in any case, all these symptoms need to be evaluated by a healthcare professional to determine the exact cause and decide on the appropriate treatment. you may not need to go to the hospital for this -- you could make an appointment with your primary care physician or a neurologist.

in the meantime, try to avoid bending your elbows for prolonged periods, for example when sleeping or when using your phone. sleeping with a splint on
